'''Sammuel Olatunbosun Shonibare''' (January 8, 1920 - January 1964) was a Nigerian businessman and politician who was a founding member of the [[Action Group (Nigeria)|Action Group]] (AG), he was an active member of the party from its formation until his death in 1964. Shonibare acted as the publicity secretary for the party and also performed fund raising duties for the Action Group.
He held the chieftaincy title of Asiwaju of Ijebu.<ref name="olu" />
== Early life and career == Born in January 1920 to the family of Sadiku Shonibare-Sanusi. His career began in 1936 as a clerk for [[United Africa Company|U.A.C]] in Ibadan where he worked from 1936 to 1942, he was then promoted Chief Clerk and book-keeper at Ijebu-Ode in 1942.<ref name="dailyex1">{{Cite news |title=Shonibare dies in London |date=January 18, 1964 |work=Daily Express (Nigeria)}}</ref> He rose to become office manager, technical department before leaving the firm in 1952. Upon leaving UAC, he joined Amalgamated Press, publishers of the Daily Service which was then a political mouth-piece of the Action Group. During his tenure, the company launched the ''Sunday Express'' an apolitical weekly magazine and also the launched ''Daily Express'' in partnership with the Thomson Group.<ref name="olu">{{Cite news |title=Shonibare's Human Touch Still Here |last=Adebanjo |first=Olu |date=January 20, 1964 |work=Daily Express}}</ref> Under his leadership, Amalgamated Press had editors like [[Bisi Onabanjo]] and [[Lateef Jakande]], two future governors.
In 1958, Shonibare became managing director of the National Investment Property Company, he was invited to be the MD by S.O. Gbadamosi, a board member.
While working for U.A.C. in [[Ijebu Ode]], his supervisor was Mr Samuel Olukoya. At party in 1942, he was introduced to his daughter Ms Alice Olukoya, they got married in 1946.
=== NIPC === He was managing director of a controversial company, National Investment and Properties Corporation, a private company that was linked with AG and the regional government and whose directors were party members. The company was formed 1958 by Action Group to evade a new legislation curtailing the use of banks to finance party activities. Previously, the party was involved in a murky arrangement with National Bank for financing.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sklar|first1=Richard L|title=Nigerian political parties: power in an emergent African nation|date=2015|isbn=069162514X|pages=455–457|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/nigerian-political-parties-power-in-an-emergent-african-nation/oclc/1027490953&referer=brief_results|language=English}}</ref> Under NIPC's relationship with AG, the private firm borrowed money from the Western regional marketing board to invest in the country. The money was used to develop some properties that included [[Cocoa House]], Ibadan and Western House, [[Broad Street, Lagos]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Low|title=Constitutional heads and political crises: Commonwealth episodes, 1945-85|date=1988|publisher=St. Martin's Press|isbn=0312021135|page=80}}</ref> In 1962, a tribunal under Justice [[G.B.A. Coker]] probed a six-million-pound loan that was extended to NIPC by the Western Region Marketing Board. At the inquiry, it was noted that NIPC was an investment arm of the Action Group to fund party activities.<ref>{{cite news|title=Akintola travelled in ambulances for protection during Wild-Wild-West crisis –Ayo Adebanjo|url=http://punchng.com/akintola-travelled-ambulances-protection-wild-wild-west-crisis-ayo-adebanjo/|work=Punch Newspapers}}</ref> The assets of NIPC were transferred to WEMABOD.
When a state of emergency became effective in the region, Shonibare was limited to Ondo town; he died in January 1964, weeks after the state of emergency was lifted. Shonibare was chairman of Amalgamated Press Ltd, [[Ikeja]], publishers of the now-defunct Daily Express and Daily Service. Prior to his death, he founded Shonny Investments which was in the process of developing Maryland Estate, he was also involved in a mobile film unit and a printing business.

{{Italic title}} {{taxobox |name = ''Salsola soda'' |image = Salsola soda Rignanese.jpg |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Core eudicots]] |ordo = [[Caryophyllales]] |familia = [[Amaranthaceae]] |subfamilia = [[Salsoloideae]] |genus = ''[[Salsola]]'' |species = '''''S. soda''''' |binomial = ''Salsola soda'' |binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]] }}
'''''Salsola soda''''', more commonly known in English as '''opposite-leaved [[Salsola|saltwort]]''', '''oppositeleaf Russian thistle,''' or '''barilla plant,''' is a small (to 0.7 m tall), annual, succulent shrub that is native to the [[Mediterranean Basin]].<ref>{{ITIS |id=504989 |taxon=''Salsola soda'' L. |accessdate=May 19, 2007}}</ref> It is a [[halophyte]] (a salt-tolerant plant) that typically grows in coastal regions and can be irrigated with salt water.
The plant has great historical importance as a source of [[soda ash]], which was extracted from the ashes of ''Salsola soda'' and other [[saltwort]] plants.<ref name="Clow52"> Clow, Archibald and Clow, Nan L. (1952). ''Chemical Revolution,'' (Ayer Co Pub, June 1952), pp. 65–90. {{ISBN|0-8369-1909-2}}.</ref> Soda ash is one of the [[alkali]] substances that are crucial in glassmaking and soapmaking. The famed clarity of 16th century [[cristallo|''cristallo'' glass]] from [[Venetian glass|Murano and Venice]] depended upon the purity of "[[Levant]]ine soda ash,"<ref> Turner, Guy (1999). "''Allume Catina'' and the Aesthetics of Venetian ''Cristallo''," ''Journal of Design History'' '''12,''' No. 2, pp. 111–122. {{doi|10.1093/jdh/12.2.111}}</ref> and the nature of this ingredient was kept secret. Spain had an enormous 18th century industry that produced soda ash from the saltworts ([[:es:barrilla|''barrilla'']] in Spanish).<ref name="Perez"> Pérez, Joaquín Fernández (1998). [https://www.webcitation.org/5W0IroD9s "From the barrilla to the Solvay factory in Torrelavega: The Manufacture of Saltwort in Spain,"] ''Antilia: The Spanish Journal of History of Natural Sciences and Technology,'' Vol. IV, Art. 1. {{ISSN|1136-2049}}. Archived at WebCite from [http://www.ucm.es/info/antilia/revista/vol4-en/ant4-1-en.htm this original URL] on 2008-03-01.</ref> Soda ash is now known to be predominantly [[sodium carbonate]]. In 1807, Sir [[Humphry Davy]] isolated a metallic element from [[caustic soda]]; he named the new element "[[sodium]]" to indicate its relationship to "soda." Before soda was somewhat synonymous (in U.S. English) with soft drinks, the word referred to ''Salsola soda'' and other [[saltwort]] plants, and to "sodas" derived from soda ash.
While the era of farming for soda ash is long past, ''S. soda'' is still cultivated as a vegetable that enjoys considerable popularity in Italy and with gourmets around the world. Its common names in Italian include ''barba di frate'', ''agretti'', and ''liscari sativa'' (short: '''lischi''' or '''lischeri'''). Of its culinary value, [[Frances Mayes]] has written that "Spinach is the closest taste, but while ''agretti'' has the mineral sharpness of spinach, it tastes livelier, full of the energy of spring."<ref> Mayes, Frances (2000). ''Bella Tuscany: The Sweet Life of Italy,'' (Broadway), p. 15. {{ISBN|0-7679-0284-X}}.</ref>
== Description == This annual, succulent plant can grow into small shrubs up to 0.7 m tall (sometimes called subshrubs). It has fleshy green leaves with either green or red stems. The tiny flowers develop from [[inflorescence]]s that grow out of the base of the leaves near the stem.<ref> Jepson, Willis Linn (1993). ''The Jepson manual: higher plants of California,'' James C. Hickman, editor (Berkeley: [[University of California Press]], 1993), p. 514. {{ISBN|0-520-08255-9}}</ref><ref name="Eflora"> Robertson, Kenneth R. and Clemants, Steven E. (1997). [http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=200006933 ''Salsola Soda''], from "Amaranthaceae" chapter, in: Flora of North America Editorial Committee, eds. 1993+. ''Flora of North America North of Mexico.'' 12+ vols. New York and Oxford. Vol. 4, pp. 399–402. {{ISBN|0-19-517389-9}}.</ref>
== Distribution == ''S. soda'' is native in Eurasia and North Africa. Historically, it was well known in Italy, Sicily, and Spain. In modern Europe, it is also found on the Atlantic coasts of France and Portugal and on the Black Sea coast.<ref> [[Jaakko Jalas|Jalas, Jaakko]] and Suominen, Juha (1989). ''Atlas Florae Europaeae: Distribution of Vascular Plants in Europe'' (Cambridge University Press, Cambridge), p. 78. {{ISBN|0-521-34271-6}}.</ref> It has become naturalized along the Pacific coast of North America,<ref> "County-Level Distribution of ''Salsola soda''," <!--Very long URL below isn't being correctly interpreted. http://www.mip.berkeley.edu:8080/servlet/SmaschCaCountyDist?taxon_name=Salsola%20soda&comp_radio=no&compare_to=no --> from [http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/db/smasch/ SMASCH] (Specimen Management for California Herbaria) database ([http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/ The University and Jepson Herbaria], University of California, Berkeley). Entry retrieved December 13, 2006.</ref> and there is concern about its [[Invasive species|invasiveness]] in California's salt marshes.<ref> California Exotic Pest Plant Council, [http://www.cal-ipc.org/ip/inventory/pdf/Inventory1999.pdf Exotic Pest Plants of Greatest Ecological Concern in California], October, 1999.</ref><ref> Baye, Peter (1998). "[http://www.cal-ipc.org/resources/news/pdf/caleppc_news878.pdf More on Salsola soda]," ''CalEPPC News'' (Newsletter of the California Exotic Pest Plant Council), Vol. 6, No. 4 (Fall 1998).</ref> It is also reported to be naturalized in South America.<ref name="Eflora" />
== Soda ash and the biology of sodium accumulation == {{see also|Soda ash|Halophyte}} The ashes obtained by the burning of ''S. soda'' can be refined to make a product called soda ash,<ref name="Clow52" /> which is one of the [[alkali]] materials essential to making [[soda-lime glass]], [[soap]], and many other products. The principal active ingredient is [[sodium carbonate]], with which the term "soda ash" is now nearly synonymous. The processed ashes of ''S. soda'' contain as much as 30% sodium carbonate.<ref> Barker, T. C., Dickinson, R., and Hardie, D. W. F. (1956). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/2550954 "The Origins of the Synthetic Alkali Industry in Britain,"] ''[[Economica]], New Series'', Vol. 23, No. 90. (May, 1956), pp. 158–171.</ref>
A high concentration of sodium carbonate in the ashes of ''S. soda'' occurs if the plant is grown in highly saline soils (i.e. in soils with a high concentration of sodium chloride), so that the plant's tissues contain a fairly high concentration of sodium ions. ''S. soda'' can be irrigated with sea water, which contains about 40 g/l of dissolved sodium chloride and other salts. When these sodium-rich plants are burned, the carbon dioxide that is produced presumably reacts with this sodium to form sodium carbonate.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}
[[Image:Rhoeo Discolor - Plasmolysis.jpg|right|thumb| Cells of the boatlily plant [http://plants.usda.gov/java/nameSearch?keywordquery=rhoeo+discolor&mode=sciname&submit.x=0&submit.y=0 ''Rhoeo discolor'']. The large pink region in each cell is a [[vacuole]]. Sodium is sequestered in vacuoles by halophyte cells.]] It is surprising to find a higher concentration of sodium than of potassium in plant tissues; the former element is usually toxic, and the latter element is essential, to the metabolic processes of plants. Thus, most plants, and especially most crop plants, are "[[glycophyte]]s", and suffer damage when planted in saline soils.<ref> Glenn, Edward P., Brown, J. Jed, and Blumwald, Eduardo (1999). "Salt Tolerance and Crop Potential of Halophytes," ''Critical Review in Plant Sciences,'' Vol. 18, No. 2, pp. 227–255. {{doi|10.1080/07352689991309207}}</ref><ref> Xiong, Liming and Zhu, Jian-Kang (2002). (September 30, 2002) "[http://www.bioone.org/perlserv/?request=get-document&doi=10.1199%2Ftab.0048 Salt Tolerance]," in Somerville, C. R. and Meyerowitz, E. M., eds, ''The Arabidopsis Book.'' American Society of Plant Biologists, Rockville, MD. {{doi|10.1199/tab.0048}}.</ref> ''S. soda'', and the other plants that were cultivated for soda ash, are "[[halophytes]]" that tolerate much more saline soils than do glycophytes, and that can thrive with much larger densities of sodium in their tissues than can glycophytes.
The biochemical processes within the cells of halophytes are typically as sensitive to sodium as are the processes in glycophytes. Sodium ions from a plant's soil or irrigation water are toxic primarily because they interfere with biochemical processes within a plant's cells that require [[potassium]], which is a chemically similar [[alkali metal]] element.<ref name="Tester"> Tester, Mark and Davenport, Romola (2003). "Na<sup>+</sup> Tolerance and Na<sup>+</sup> Transport in Higher Plants," [http://www.aob.oupjournals.org ''Annals of Botany''] '''91''': 503-527. {{doi|10.1093/aob/mcg058}}.</ref> The cell of a [[halophyte]] such as ''S. soda'' has a molecular transport mechanism that sequesters sodium ions into a compartment within the [[plant cell]] called a "[[Vacuole#Plants|vacuole]]." The vacuole of a plant cell can occupy 80% of the cell's volume; most of a halophyte plant cell's sodium can be sequestered in the vacuole, leaving the rest of the cell with a tolerable ratio of sodium to potassium ions.
In addition to ''S. soda'', soda ash has also been produced from the ashes of ''[[Salsola kali]]'' (another [[saltwort]] plant), of [[glasswort]] plants, and of [[kelp]], a type of seaweed. The sodium carbonate, which is water-soluble, is "[[wikt:lixiviate|lixiviated]]" from the ashes (extracted with water), and the resulting solution is boiled dry to obtain the finished soda ash product. A very similar process is used to obtain [[potash]] (mainly [[potassium carbonate]]) from the ashes of hardwood trees. Because halophytes must also have potassium ions in their tissues, even the best soda ash derived from them also contains some potash (potassium carbonate), as was known by the 19th century.<ref name="Clow52" /><ref> Porcher, Francis Peyre (1863). ''Resources of the Southern Fields and Forests, Medical, Economical, and Agricultural. Being also a Medical Botany of the Confederate States; with Practical Information on the Useful Properties of the Trees, Plants, and Shrubs,'' (Evans and Cogswell, Charleston), p. 133. Online version at http://docsouth.unc.edu/imls/porcher/porcher.html (retrieved November 28, 2006).</ref>
Plants were a very important source of soda ash until the early 19th century. In the 18th century, Spain had an enormous industry producing ''[[barilla]]'' (one type of plant-derived soda ash) from saltwort plants.<ref name="Perez" /> Similarly, [[Scotland]] had a large 18th-century industry producing soda ash from kelp; this industry was so lucrative that it led to overpopulation in the [[Western Isles]] of Scotland, and one estimate is that 100,000 people were occupied with "kelping" during the summer months.<ref name="Clow52" /> The commercialization of the [[Leblanc process]] for synthesizing sodium carbonate (from salt, [[limestone]], and [[sulfuric acid]]) brought an end to the era of farming for soda ash in the first half of the 19th century.
[[Image:Salsola soda.jpg|thumb|right| Freshly harvested ''agretti'' (''S. soda'')]] [[Image:Barba frate saltata con cipolla e pancetta.jpg|thumb|''Agretti'' cooked with onions and bacon]]
== Cultivation and culinary uses == The Italian name ''agretti'' is commonly used in English to refer to the edible leaves of ''S. soda''; ''barba di frate'' (or friar's beard) is the most common of the Italian names. This plant is not a summer green and should be started early indoors or in autumn. The seed is notorious for poor [[germination]] at about 30 to 40% standard, much like [[rosemary]]. Though the plant is often grown in saltwater-irrigated land in the [[Mediterranean Basin]], it will grow without salt water. ''S. soda'' is harvested in bunches when small, or cropped regularly to encourage new growth when mature. It is most commonly boiled and eaten as a [[leafy vegetable]]; the recommendation is to cook it in boiling water until the leaves soften, and to serve while some bite (crunch) remains (much like [[Glasswort#Culinary|samphire]]). It can also be eaten raw; it is said to "taste grassy and slightly salty with a pleasant, crunchy texture." <ref>Lennartson, Margi (2005). ''Organic Vegetable Production'' (The Crowood Press, Ltd, ), p. 247. {{ISBN|1-86126-788-6}}.</ref>
''S. soda'' is sometimes confused with a plant known in Japan as ''okahijiki'' (land seaweed), which is actually the species ''S. komarovi''. The harvested leaves of the two species have a similar appearance.
== Phytoremediation == ''S. soda'' has also been studied as a [[bioremediation]] "biodesalinating companion plant" for crops such as tomatoes and peppers when they are grown in saline soils.<ref> Colla, G., Rouphael, Y., Fallovo, C., and Cardarelli, M. (2006). "Use of ''Salsola soda'' as a companion plant to improve greenhouse pepper (''Capsicum annuum'') performance under saline conditions," ''New Zealand Journal of Crop and Horticultural Science'', Vol. 34: 283 - 290. Online abstract at http://www.rsnz.org/publish/nzjchs/2006/039.php (retrieved November 28, 2006).</ref> The ''Salsola soda'' extracts enough sodium from the soil to improve the growth of the crop plant, and better crop yields result despite the competition of the two plants for the remaining minerals from the soil.
== See also == *[[Phytoremediation|Phytoremediation plants]] *[[Hyperaccumulators table – 3]]

{{other uses}} {{Infobox building | name = Singer Building | image = SingerBuilding crop.jpg | image_size = 250px | highest_prev = [[Philadelphia City Hall]] | highest_next = [[Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Tower]] | highest_start = 1908 | highest_end = 1909 | location = 149 [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]]
[[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | coordinates = {{coord|40.70982|-74.01001|region:US-NY|display=inline,title}} |map_type = Lower Manhattan#New York#USA | pushpin_label =Singer Building | completion_date = 1908 | demolished_date = 1968 | status = demolished | building_type = Commercial offices | antenna_spire = | roof = {{convert|186.6|m|abbr=on}} | top_floor = | floor_count = 47 | elevator_count = | cost = | floor_area = | architect = [[Ernest Flagg]] | structural_engineer= Boller & Hodge | main_contractor = General Supply & Construction Company | developer = | owner = | management = | references = {{emporis|102519}}{{skyscraperpage|1031}}{{structurae|s0002471}} }} The '''Singer Building''' or '''Singer Tower''', at [[Liberty Street (Manhattan)|Liberty Street]] and [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] in [[Lower Manhattan]]'s [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]], in the [[U.S. state]] of [[New York (state)|New York]], was a 47-story office building completed in 1908 as the headquarters of the [[Singer Corporation|Singer Manufacturing Company]].{{cite journal |last=Ripley |first=Charles M. |date=October 1907 |title=A Building Forty-Seven Stories High |journal=[[World's Work|The World's Work: A History of Our Time]] |volume=XIV |issue= |pages=9459–9461 |accessdate=2009-07-10 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sojNAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA9459}} It was the [[Skyscraper#History of the tallest skyscrapers|tallest building in the world]] from 1908 to 1909. It was torn down in 1968, together with the adjacent [[City Investing Building]], and is now the site of [[One Liberty Plaza]]. When it was razed, it became the [[List of tallest voluntarily demolished buildings|tallest building ever to be demolished]],{{cite web |url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20535821 |title = How do you demolish a skyscraper? |author = Jon Kelly |publisher = BBC |date = 6 December 2012 |work = BBC News Magazine |accessdate= 12 December 2012 }} and is currently the third-tallest building ever to be destroyed (after the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] towers) and the tallest to be purposely demolished by its owner. ==History== ===Construction and design=== The building was commissioned by [[Frederick Gilbert Bourne|Frederick Bourne]], the head of the Singer Sewing Machine Company. He hired architect [[Ernest Flagg]], who was an early exponent of the [[Beaux arts architecture|Beaux-Arts]] architectural style.{{cite news|url=http://travel.nytimes.com/2005/01/02/realestate/02scap.html|title=Streetscapes: Once the Tallest Building, but Since 1967 a Ghost|last=Gray|first=Christopher|date=2 January 2005|work=The New York Times|accessdate=1 August 2010}} Flagg had also designed the company's previous headquarters at 561 Broadway between Prince and [[Spring Street (Manhattan)|Spring]] Streets—in what is now the [[SoHo]] neighborhood—which was referred to as the "Little Singer Building" after the new building was erected.{{cite AIA4}}, p.100{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/29/realestate/style-standard-for-early-steel-framed-skyscraper.html?scp=896&sq=corning&st=nyt|title=Style Standard for Early Steel-Framed Skyscraper|last=Gray|first=Christopher|date=29 June 1997|work=The New York Times|page=7|accessdate=1 August 2010}} Plans and working drawings were prepared by [[George W. Conable]].{{cite web|url=http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=7335|title=National Register of Historic Places Registration: Jamaica Chamber of Commerce Building|date=April 1983|accessdate=2011-01-16|author=Larry E. Gobrecht|publisher=[[New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6GpIFGIXR?url=http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=7335|archivedate=2013-05-23|df=}} Flagg believed that buildings more than 10 or 15 stories high should be set back from the street, with the tower occupying only a quarter of the lot. The 12-story base of the building filled an entire blockfront, while the tower above was relatively narrow. The tower floors were squares 65 feet (20 m) on a side. ''[[New York Times]]'' architectural critic [[Christopher Gray]] wrote in 2005:
The lobby had the quality of "celestial radiance" seen in world's-fair and exposition architecture of the period, as the author Mardges Bacon described it in her 1986 monograph "Ernest Flagg" (Architectural History Foundation, MIT Press). A forest of marble columns rose high to a series of multiple small domes of delicate plasterwork, and Flagg trimmed the columns with bronze beading. A series of large bronze medallions placed at the top of the columns were alternately rendered in the monogram of the Singer company and, quite inventively, as a huge needle, thread and bobbin.
At {{Convert|612|ft|m}} tall, the Singer Building was the tallest office building in the world from its completion in 1908 until the completion in 1909 of the {{convert|700|ft|m|adj=on}} [[Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Tower]] at [[23rd Street (Manhattan)|23rd Street]] and [[Madison Avenue]] in Manhattan. ===Early history and tenants=== As of November 1921, [[Catham and Phenix National Bank]] had its main office in the Singer Building.{{Citation | date =November 8, 1921 | title =Catham & Phenix Completes Merger; Buys Control in New York County National, to Be Made a Twelfth Branch. Expansion Policy is Old - Larger Institution Has Increased Its Trade Centres Ever Since Middle of Last Century. | publisher =''[[The New York Times]]'' | publication-place =New York City | page =37 | url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D0DEEDB1431EF33A2575BC0A9679D946095D6CF&legacy=true | accessdate =February 16, 2017}} ===Later history and demolition=== In 1961, Singer sold the building and subsequently moved to [[Rockefeller Center]].{{cite news|url=https://select.nytimes.com/mem/archive/pdf?res=F10710F6345F1A718DDDAB0A94D0405B878AF1D3|title=Landmark on Lower Broadway to Go|last=Fried|first=Joseph P.|date=Aug 22, 1967|work=The New York Times|accessdate=2 August 2010}} The building was then acquired by real estate developer [[William Zeckendorf]], who sought unsuccessfully for the [[New York Stock Exchange]] to move there. In 1964, [[United States Steel]] acquired the building, along with the neighboring [[City Investing Building]], for demolition. By the 1960s, the building was uneconomical because of its small interior dimensions. The tower portion of the building contained only {{convert|4200|sqft|m2}} per floor, compared with {{convert|37000|sqft|m2}} per floor of the building that replaced it, the U.S. Steel Building (currently known as [[One Liberty Plaza]]). Although New York had a newly created [[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission|Landmarks Preservation Commission]] by the time demolition commenced in 1967, and the Singer Building was considered to be one of the most iconic buildings in the city, it did not receive landmark designation, which would have prevented it from being torn down. Alan Burnham, executive director of the commission, said in August 1967 that if the building were to have been made a landmark, the city would have to either find a buyer for it or acquire it. Demolition commenced in August 1967 and was completed the following year. At the time, it was the tallest building ever to be destroyed until the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]], when the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] one block over collapsed. The Singer Building is currently the third-tallest building to be destroyed but is still the tallest building whose razing was anticipated.{{cite AIA4}}, p.42 {{clear}} ==Gallery== File:Singer City Investing Hudson Terminal 1909 crop.jpg|Singer Building with the [[Hudson Terminal]] File:SingerBuilding2.jpg|The building seen from Broadway File:SingerBuilding15.jpg|The interior view of the lobby mezzanine ==See also== *[[Early skyscrapers]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|149 Broadway Singer Building}} *[http://www.bc.edu/bc_org/avp/cas/fnart/fa267/20th/singer1.jpg Old postcard view of the Singer Building on bc.edu] *[http://www.nyc-architecture.com/SOH/SOH001.htm The Little Singer Building (561 Broadway)] *[http://nyc-architecture.com/?p=1497 The Lost Skyscrapers of Bygone New York] {{S-start}} {{S-ach|rec}} {{S-bef|rows=2|before=[[Philadelphia City Hall]]}} {{S-ttl|title=[[Skyscraper#History of the tallest skyscrapers|Tallest building in the world]]|years=1908–1909
187 m}} {{S-aft|rows=2|after=[[Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Tower]]}} {{S-ttl|title=[[List of tallest buildings in the United States|Tallest building in the United States]]|years=1908–1909
187 m}} {{Succession box | before=[[Park Row Building]] | title=[[List of tallest buildings in New York#Timeline of tallest buildings|Tallest building in New York]] | years=1906–1909
187 m | after=[[Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Tower]] }} {{S-end}} {{Broadway (Manhattan)}} {{Buildings in New York City timeline}} [[Category:Headquarters in the United States]] [[Category:Destroyed landmarks in New York (state)]] [[Category:Demolished buildings and structures in New York City]] [[Category:Former world's tallest buildings]] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Manhattan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures demolished in 1968]] [[Category:Former skyscrapers]] [[Category:Broadway (Manhattan)]] [[Category:Financial District, Manhattan]] [[Category:1908 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Beaux-Arts architecture in New York City]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1908]] [[Category:Trust Company of America]]

'''Sorin Ovidiu Vîntu''' ({{IPA-ro|soˈrin oˈvidju ˈvɨntu}}; 23 November 1955, [[Bucharest]]) is a Romanian businessman and owner of the [[Realitatea-Caţavencu]] media company. In 2008 he was considered the 5th richest man in [[Romania]] with an estimated [[net worth]] between 800 and 850 million euros.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.wall-street.ro/articol/Marketing-PR/50406/Cum-arata-topul-celor-mai-bogati-miliardari-din-Romania.html Cum arata topul celor mai bogati miliardari din Romania]</ref>
On June 16, 2009, during a TV interview on [[B1 TV]], president [[Traian Băsescu]] accused Vântu of tax evasion by allegedly not paying 60 million euros worth of [[Value Added Tax]]. Vântu later denied the accusation, and sued Băsescu for [[libel]], asking for 1 million euros in damages.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.mediafax.ro/social/sorin-ovidiu-vantu-l-a-dat-in-judecata-pe-traian-basescu-4627565 Sorin Ovidiu Vântu l-a dat în judecată pe Traian Băsescu]</ref>
Vântu was sentenced to two years in prison in 2005 for using some false documents to gain majority shares in the Investment and Development Bank (BID), which went bankrupt in 2002. Later the [[Bucharest Court of Appeals]] ordered by final decision the discontinuation of the trial finding that the charges passed their [[statute of limitations]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediafax.ro/english/statute-of-limitations-rids-romanian-businessman-s-o-vantu-of-forgery-charges-5017600 |title=Statute Of Limitations Rids Romanian Businessman S.O. Vantu Of Forgery Charges |publisher=Mediafax.ro |date= |accessdate=2011-12-25}}</ref>
On June 21 2012, he was sentenced to one year in prison following the blackmail accusation of his ex business partner, Sebastian Ghiță.<ref name="condg2012-06-21">[http://www.adevarul.ro/actualitate/eveniment/actualitate-sorin_ovidiu_vintu-sov-sebastian_ghita-santaj-condamnare-6_luni_0_722927858.html UPDATE SOV, un an de închisoare cu executare. ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623193150/http://www.adevarul.ro/actualitate/eveniment/actualitate-sorin_ovidiu_vintu-sov-sebastian_ghita-santaj-condamnare-6_luni_0_722927858.html |date=2012-06-23 }}, Andrei Aștefănesei, ''Adevărul'' (romanian). Retrieved 2012-06-21.</ref>
In September 2010 he was briefly arrested, being accused of having helped [[Nicolae Popa (businessman)|Nicolae Popa]], the former CEO of BID.
On February 21, 2016, he was sentenced to eight years in prison for a ponzi scheme. <ref>[http://www.business-review.eu/news/sorin-ovidiu-vintu-sentenced-to-eight-years-in-prison-for-ponzi-scheme-fund-fni-130993 Home » News » Sorin Ovidiu Vintu sentenced to eight years in prison for ponzi scheme fund FNI Sorin Ovidiu Vintu sentenced to eight years in prison for ponzi scheme fund FNI], Georgiana Bendre, ''Business Review''. Retrieved 2017-02-22.</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox street | name = Spring Street | native_name = | marker_image = | image = New York City Fire Museum 002.jpg | image_size = 275px | caption = [[New York City Fire Museum]], a former [[firehouse]],
at 278 Spring Street | other_name = | former_names = Brannon Street | postal_code = 10012, 10013[http://maps.huge.info/zip.htm] | addresses = | length_m = | length_ft = | length_mi = | length_km = | length_ref = | width = | location = [[Hudson Square]], [[SoHo]], and [[Nolita]]
([[Manhattan]], [[New York City]]) | client = | maint = | coordinates = {{coord|40.724527|-74.001982|type:landmark_globe:earth_region:US-NY|display=title,inline}} | direction_a = West | terminus_a = [[West Side Highway|West Street]] | direction_b = East | terminus_b = [[Bowery]] | junction = | commissioning_date = | construction_start_date = | completion_date = | inauguration_date = | demolition_date = | north = Prince Street | south = [[Delancey Street|Kenmare Street]] | east = | west = }} '''Spring Street''' is a street in [[Lower Manhattan]], [[New York City]], which runs west–east, through the neighborhoods of [[Hudson Square]], [[SoHo, Manhattan|SoHo]], and [[Nolita]]. It runs parallel to and between Dominick, [[Broome Street|Broome]], and [[Kenmare Street]]s (to the south), and Vandam and Prince Streets (to the north).[https://maps.google.com/maps?q=Spring+Street,+New+York,+NY&hl=en&ll=40.72225,-73.996654&spn=0.017498,0.042272&sll=40.697488,-73.979681&sspn=0.560155,1.352692&oq=Spring+S&hnear=Spring+St,+New+York&t=m&z=15 "Spring Street"] on [[Google Maps]]{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7nsrosfxk90C&pg=PA10&dq=%22spring+street%22+%22manhattan%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=37kOUanEH8m20QHE8YD4CA&ved=0CMEBEOgBMBo#v=onepage&q=%22spring%20street%22%20%22manhattan%22&f=false |title=The Feder Guide to Where to Park Your Car in Manhattan (and Where Not to Park It!) |author=Feder, Erik |publisher=Rhythmo Productions |year=2005 |accessdate=February 4, 2013}} The street's addresses begin from the [[Bowery]] and run ascending to Spring Street's end at [[West Street]], which runs along the [[Hudson River]].[http://gis.nyc.gov/doitt/nycitymap/?z=8&p=985889,202030&c=GISBasic&s=a:1,SPRING+STREET,MANHATTAN "1 Spring Street"] on the New York City Geographic Information System map[http://gis.nyc.gov/doitt/nycitymap/?z=8&p=981349,203707&c=GISBasic&s=a:350,SPRING+STREET,MANHATTAN "350 Spring Street"] on the New York City Geographic Information System map As it passes through the center of SoHo, Spring Street is known for its artists' lofts, restaurants, and trendy and high-end boutiques, as well as its collection of [[cast-iron architecture|cast-iron buildings]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WXAtAzhcjgkC&pg=PA47&dq=%22spring+street%22+fashion&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HV8PUfzFOcHD0QGk0oCACA&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22spring%20street%22%20fashion&f=false |title=Pocket Rough Guide New York City |author1=Rosenberg, Andrew |author2=Dunford, Martin |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher= Penguin|year= 2011|accessdate=February 4, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/the-scene/shopping/NY-TAXI-Spring-Street-Shopping-Guide-131514778.html |title=Spring Street Shopping Guide |publisher=NBC New York |date= |accessdate=February 4, 2013}} ==History== [[File:Lispenards meadow Broadway and Spring A Anderson 1785.gif|thumb|left|375px|Lispenard's Meadow in 1785, viewed from what is now the northeast corner of Spring Street and Broadway]] [[Aaron Burr]]'s estate, Richmond Hill, was located in the area in the 1790s. Burr dammed [[Minetta Creek]] to create an ornamental pool by his estate's main gate, which was located near where Spring Street, [[MacDougal Street]] and [[Sixth Avenue (Manhattan)|Sixth Avenue]] come together.Burrows & Wallace, p.325 In 1803, what would become Spring Street was the only street through the area, which was still rural, hilly and wooded.{{cite web|url=http://s-media.nyc.gov/agencies/lpc/arch_reports/1139.pdf |author=Office of Chief Medical Examiner of the City of New York |title=ARCHAEOLOGICAL INVESTIGATIONS OF THE SPRING STREET PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH CEMETERY; Appendix A: New York City Office of Chief Medical Examiner – Report of Findings|publisher= |date=February 14, 2007 |accessdate=April 1, 2016}} In May 1805, the street was ordered widened to 65 feet by the [[New York City Council|Common Council]] of the City of New York.{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/minutesofcommonc04newy/minutesofcommonc04newy_djvu.txt |title=Full text of "Minutes of the Common Council of the City of New York, 1784–1831" |author=Common Council of the City of New York |publisher=Archive.org |date=May 27, 1805 |accessdate=February 5, 2013}} [[File:St. Nicholas Hotel, Broadway, New York, from Robert N. Dennis collection crop.jpg|thumb|right|280px|The St. Nicholas Hotel, no longer extant]] The street was named Brannon Street until 1806,{{cite web|url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/reports/2486.pdf |title=Dennison and Lydia Wood House, 310 Spring Street |publisher=nyc.gov|date=March 27, 2012 |accessdate=February 4, 2013}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uow9AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA376&lpg=PA376&dq=%22spring+street%22+%22brannon+street%22&source=bl&ots=tqjpyO8DRk&sig=tWIUBwmJmniTKAu8Yy2SjVwW84s&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8uMOUbazJ6y20AHaqICIBg&ved=0CFYQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=%22spring%20street%22%20%22brannon%20street%22&f=false |title=The Market Book: Containing a Historical Account of the Public Markets of the Cities of New York, Boston, Philadelphia and Brooklyn, with a Brief Description of Every Article of Human Food Sold Therein, the Introduction of Cattle in America, and Notices of Many Remarkable Specimens, Volume 1|author1=De Voe |author2=Thomas Farrington |publisher= Markets|year= 1862|accessdate=February 4, 2013}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ov8aAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA143&lpg=PA143&dq=%22spring+street%22+%22brannon+street%22&source=bl&ots=wgDsGzbuch&sig=rpZtjB-5phKSQ6CvPh_7g3vIeF4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8uMOUbazJ6y20AHaqICIBg&ved=0CFkQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22spring%20street%22%20%22brannon%20street%22&f=false |author=Supreme Court, New York Special Term|title=The New York State Reporter |publisher=W. C. Little & Co. |year=1895|accessdate=February 4, 2013}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tisWAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA171&lpg=PA171&dq=%22spring+street%22+%22brannon+street%22&source=bl&ots=jppuVlDoL8&sig=oyDNJd6_Zz8HCz5ZoxRh45AfDTQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8uMOUbazJ6y20AHaqICIBg&ved=0CF4Q6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=%22spring%20street%22%20%22brannon%20street%22&f=false |title=Minutes of the Common Council of the City of New York, 1784–1831 – New York (N.Y.). |author1=Common Council and Peterson |author2=Arthur Everett |publisher= |year=1917 |accessdate=February 4, 2013}} because it ran through the garden of a man by that name at what is now Spring Street and [[Hudson Street (Manhattan)|Hudson Street]].[http://sohomemory.com/tag/lispenards-meadow/ "Lispernard's Meadow"] on the SoHo Memory project website.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=v4cGmMe6_okC&oi=fnd&pg=PR7&dq=%22new+york%22+%22brannon+street%22&ots=hn2pRsEfCb&sig=_SXeZ8d4pJ42seIIdRwhgR5eKWw#v=onepage&q=%20%22brannon%20street%22&f=false |title=Historical Guide to the City of New York |author=City History Club of New York |publisher=F. A. Stokes Company |year=1909 |accessdate=February 5, 2013}} Its current name comes from a [[fresh water]] [[spring (hydrology)|spring]] which ran through Lispenard's Meadow, at the place where [[West Broadway]] is now.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4P8JAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA33&dq=%22spring+street%22+%22manhattan%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=37kOUanEH8m20QHE8YD4CA&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22spring%20street%22%20%22manhattan%22&f=false |title=A geological history of Manhattan or New York Island: together with a map of the island, and a suite of sections, tables and columns, for the study of geology, particularly adapted for the American student |author=Cozzens, Issachar|publisher=W.E. Dean |year= 1843|accessdate=February 4, 2013}} The stream continues to run underground, occasionally flooding basements.{{cite streetbook}} p.96 In 1834, anti-black [[Race riot#Nativist Period 1700s-1860|race rioters]], primarily [[Irish American#18th to mid-19th century|Irish immigrants]], broke into the Spring Street Presbyterian Church, the home church of [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionist]] [[Henry G. Ludlow|Dr. Henry G. Ludlow]]. It was at the time located at 250 Spring Street between [[Varick Street]] and Sixth Avenue, where it had been established in 1811. The rioters caused extensive damage to the church's organ, pews and galleries. Two years after the riot, in 1836, a [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic Revival]] structure was completed, replacing the old church. It stood on the site until the 1960s. In the early 20th century, the church served an impoverished community in which, according to the pastor, "Much of the neighborhood was lost in a kind of sodden apathy to which drunken quarrels brought release."Burrows & Wallace, p.558{{cite fromatoz}}, p.264{{cite fednyc}}, p. 80 The corner of Spring Street and [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] was the location of the [[St. Nicholas Hotel (New York City)|St. Nicholas Hotel]], a six-story, marble-faced, 600-room luxury establishment that was designed by either [[J. B. Snook]] or [[Griffith Thomas]], and was completed in 1853. It was equipped with the newest technological conveniences, such as [[central heating]], hot running water, and a [[telegraph]] office in the lobby. The interior of the hotel featured [[frescoes]] on the ceiling, [[gas light]] [[chandelier]]s and walnut [[wainscotting]]. The opulence of the hotel was such that one visitor described a stay there as: "like an introduction to the palace of some Eastern prince."Burrows & Wallace, p.671 The building took up the full block between Spring and Broome Streets; only two small segments survive.[[New York Landmarks Preservation Commission]] [http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/reports/SoHo_HD.pdf "NYCLPC SoHo – Cast-Iron Historic District Designation Report"] (August 14, 1873) p. 40White et al., p. 114[[commons:File:521-523 Broadway St. Nicholas Hotel.jpg|"521–523 Broadway St. Nicholas Hotel"]]{{clear left}} ==Notable places == [[File:Germania 190 Bowery jeh crop.JPG|thumb|240px|The [[Germania Bank Building (New York)|Germania Bank Building]]]] [[File:Ear Inn 326 Spring jeh.JPG|thumb|240px|The [[James Brown House (New York)|James Brown House]]; to the right is the Urban Glass House]] [[File:Spring Street salt shed 2015-11 jeh.JPG|thumb|240px|Spring Street salt shed at west end of street]] *The '''[[Germania Bank Building (New York)|Germania Bank Building]]''', on the northwest corner of Spring Street and the Bowery (190 Bowery), a granite and limestone 1899 [[Renaissance Revival architecture|Renaissance Revival-style]] structure designed by [[Robert Maynicke]], currently the 75-room residence, studio and gallery of commercial photographer [[Jay Maisel]], who once rented space to [[Roy Lichtenstein]].White, et al., p. 93{{cite nycland}}, p.47Goodman, Wendy. [http://nymag.com/realestate/vu/2008/09/50481/ "Is 190 Bowery the Greatest Real-Estate Coup of All Time?"], ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' (September 21, 2008) *'''[[Jen Bekman Gallery]]''', 6 Spring Street west of the Bowery, an art gallery.{{cite web|url=http://www.jenbekman.com/ |title=Jen Bekman homepage |publisher=jen bekman |date=January 22, 2013 |accessdate=February 4, 2013}} *'''[[Wooster on Spring|11 Spring Street]]''', a former stable and [[carriage house]] built in 1888, was once a noted magnet for [[graffiti]] artists, who covered the exterior of the building with their artwork. When the building was purchased for conversion into condominiums, the developers, in collaboration with the [[Wooster Collective]], mounted a show inside the building, inviting well-known graffitists – many of whom had work on the outside – to cover the entire five floors of the building's interior. The show opened in December 2006 for a few days, before work on the conversion began and the artwork was covered over or destroyed.Kennedy, Randy [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/14/arts/design/14graf.html?_r=0 "Last Hurrah for Street Art, as Canvas Goes Condo"] ''[[New York Times]]'' (December 14, 2006) Prior to its days as a canvas for graffiti, the stable had been the home of [[IBM]] employee John Simpson for 30 years. Simpson had filled it with [[Rube Goldberg]]-like mechanisms, and put burnt candles, surplus from the [[1964 New York World's Fair]], in the windows, giving the building its nickname at the time, the "Candle Building". *'''[[Lombardi's Pizza]]''', 32 Spring Street, the first pizzeria in the United States. ''Zagats'' gave it a food rating of 25 in 2013.{{cite book|url=http://www.zagat.com/r/lombardis-manhattan |title=Lombardi's | Manhattan | Restaurant Menus and Reviews |publisher=Zagat |date= |accessdate=February 4, 2013}} Originally located at 53{{1/2}} Spring Street in 1897, [[Gennaro Lombardi]] converted his grocery store into a pizzeria in 1905, and had a loyal clientele, including Italian tenor [[Enrico Caruso]]. Gennaro later passed the restaurant to his son George. It was closed in 1984, and re-opened a few years later down the block, run by one of Gennaro's grandsons.{{cite inside}}, p. 195 *'''[[DeSalvio Playground]]''', on the corner of Spring Street and [[Mulberry Street (Manhattan)|Mulberry Street]], named after John DeSalvio and his son [[Louis DeSalvio|Louis]]. The elder DeSalvio was an influential man in [[Little Italy, Manhattan|Little Italy]], and his son was elected to the [[New York State Assembly]]. *'''[[Taïm]]''', 45 Spring Street, Israeli vegetarian restaurant. ''[[Zagats]]'' gave it a food rating of 26 in 2013, and ranked it the # 1 Israeli restaurant in New York City, and the # 2 restaurant in NoLita.{{cite book|author=McGratty, Clayton|url=http://www.zagat.com/r/ta%C3%AFm-manhattan-0 |title=Taïm | Manhattan | Restaurant Menus and Reviews |publisher=Zagat |date= |accessdate=February 4, 2013}} *The '''East River Savings Bank Building''' (now known as "The Spring"), 60 Spring Street, was built in 1927 and was designed by notable architect [[Cass Gilbert]] in the [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts style]]. It was converted into a condominium apartment building in 2003.[http://streeteasy.com/nyc/building/spring-condominium "Building: SPRING at 225 Lafayette Street in Nolita"] on the StreetEasy website *'''[[Balthazar (restaurant)|Balthazar]]''', 80 Spring Street, French [[brasserie]] restaurant. ''Zagats'' gave it a food rating of 24 in 2013, and ranked it the # 2 brasserie in New York City.{{cite book|url=http://www.zagat.com/r/balthazar-manhattan |title=Balthazar | Manhattan | Restaurant Menus and Reviews |publisher=Zagat |date= |accessdate=February 4, 2013}} *'''[[MoMA|MoMA Design Store]]''', 81 Spring Street (at the corner of Crosby Street). *The '''[[Donald Judd|Donald Judd House and Museum]]''', 101 Spring Street, a five-story cast-iron building, designed in 1870, which was the former residence and studio of artist [[Donald Judd]].Hamilton, William. [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/23/garden/23judd.html "The Proto-Loft, Reborn"] ''[[New York Times]]'' (March 23, 2006){{cite web|last=Bui |first=Phong |url=http://brooklynrail.org/2010/04/artseen/donald-judd-and-1o1-spring-street |title=DONALD JUDD AND 1O1 SPRING STREET |publisher=The Brooklyn Rail |date=April 17, 2010 |accessdate=February 4, 2013}}White et al., p. 116 The building has been called an "outstanding example" of cast-iron architecture. *'''175 Spring Street''', a lumber company, originally built as an electrical substation for the [[Sixth Avenue Elevated]] train line, run by the Metropolitan Railway Company. The building was constructed c. 1885, and features a granite [[Romanesque Revival architecture|Romanesque Revival]] arch.[http://www.nysonglines.com/spring.htm "Spring Street"] on New York City SonglinesWhite et al., p.124 *'''[[Vesuvio Playground]]''', on the corner of Spring Street and [[Thompson Street (Manhattan)|Thompson Street]]; a neighborhood park.{{cite news |last=Dobkin |first=Jake |url=http://gothamist.com/2006/04/24/playground_myst.php |title=Playground Mystery on Thompson Street Solved |publisher=Gothamist |date=April 24, 2006 |accessdate=February 4, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404140559/http://gothamist.com/2006/04/24/playground_myst.php |archivedate=April 4, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} *'''[[Numero 28|Numero 28 Pizzeria Romana]]''', 196 Spring Street, Italian restaurant. ''Zagats'' gave it a food rating of 24 in 2013.{{cite book|url=http://www.zagat.com/r/no-28-manhattan-0 |title=Numero 28 | Manhattan | Restaurant Menus and Reviews |publisher=Zagat |date= |accessdate=February 4, 2013}} *'''[[Aquagrill]]''', 210 Spring Street, seafood restaurant, ''Zagats'' gave it a food rating of 27 in 2013.{{cite book|url=http://www.zagat.com/r/aquagrill-manhattan |title=Aquagrill | Manhattan | Restaurant Menus and Reviews |publisher=Zagat |date= |accessdate=February 4, 2013}} *'''[[Trump SoHo]]''', 246 Spring Street, $450 million, 46-story hotel condominium.{{cite web|url=http://www.trumphotelcollection.com/soho/ |title=SoHo Hotels New York City | Trump SoHo New York |publisher=Trumphotelcollection.com |date= |accessdate=February 4, 2013}} *'''[[New York City Fire Museum]]''', 278 Spring Street (between [[Varick Street]] and [[Hudson Street (Manhattan)|Hudson Street]]). Retired 1904 Beaux-Arts specialized firehouse has over 10,000 artifacts relating to the history of [[firefighting]] and the [[New York City Fire Department]].White, et al., p.187 *'''[[List of New York City Designated Landmarks in Manhattan below 14th Street|Dennison and Lydia Wood House]]''', 310 Spring Street, landmark designated by the [[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]]. *'''[[James Brown House (New York)|James Brown House]]''', 326 Spring Street, an historic building completed in 1817, and a [[List of New York City Landmarks|New York City landmark]], listed as well on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. It is one of the few existing examples of [[Federal architecture]] in the neighborhood. The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission called it "a modest survivor of one of those charming, comfortable, small early nineteenth century houses, once abundant in [New York] City."[[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]] [http://www.neighborhoodpreservationcenter.org/db/bb_files/JAMES-BROWN-HOUSE.pdf "James Brown House Designation Report"] (November 19, 1969) On the building's ground floor is The Ear Inn, one of the oldest taverns in New York City. *The '''Urban Glass House''', 330 Spring Street (between Washington and Greenwich Streets), a 12-story luxury condominium designed by noted architect [[Philip Johnson]] in the [[Modernist architecture|Modernist]] style; the interiors are by [[Annabelle Selldorf]], another noted architect.[http://streeteasy.com/nyc/building/the-urban-glass-house "Building: The Urban Glass House at 330 Spring Street in Soho"] on the StreetEasy website The building was the last designed by Johnson before his death. The building utilized [[air rights]] from the [[James Brown House (New York)|James Brown House]] (''see'' below), and in return the developers paid for significant repairs and improvements to that landmark.Lombino, David. [http://www.nysun.com/new-york/gleaming-urban-glass-house-astonishes-spring/42921/ "A Gleaming Urban Glass House Astonishes Spring Street"] ''[[New York Sun]]'' (November 6, 2006) The building was constructed from 2005–2006.[http://gis.nyc.gov/doitt/nycitymap/?z=8&p=981566,203708&c=GISBasic&s=a:330,SPRING+STREET,MANHATTAN "330 Spring Street"] on the New York City Geographic Information Systems map][http://www.cityrealty.com/nyc/soho/urban-glass-house-330-spring-street/31145 "Urban Glass House"] on the CityRealty website ===Subway stations=== [[File:Spring Street IRT 005.jpg|thumb|240px|[[Spring Street (IRT Lexington Avenue Line)|Spring Street Station]] mosaic]] *[[Spring Street (IRT Lexington Avenue Line)|Spring Street]], a local [[metro station|station]] on the [[IRT Lexington Avenue Line]] of the [[New York City Subway]], located at the intersection of Spring and [[Lafayette Street (Manhattan)|Lafayette]] Streets, served by the {{NYCS trains|Lexington local|bold}}. *[[Spring Street (IND Eighth Avenue Line)|Spring Street]], a local station on the [[IND Eighth Avenue Line]] of the New York City Subway, located at Spring Street and [[Sixth Avenue (Manhattan)|Sixth Avenue]] in the [[Hudson Square]] neighborhood, served by the {{NYCS trains|Eighth south local|bold}}.{{NYCS const|map}} ==Notable residents== *[[Willy Eisenhart]], writer on art.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/01/obituaries/willy-eisenhart-48-art-writer-is-dead.html |title=Willy Eisenhart, 48, Art Writer, Is Dead |publisher=New York Times |date=July 1, 1995 |accessdate=February 8, 2013}} *[[Donald Judd]], artist, lived and worked at 101 Spring Street William L. Hamilton (March 23, 2006), [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/23/garden/23judd.html The Proto-Loft, Reborn] ''[[New York Times]]''. *[[Jonathan Larson]] (1960–96), [[composer]] and playwright (''[[Rent (musical)|Rent]]'' and ''[[tick, tick... BOOM!]]''), winner of a posthumous [[Pulitzer Prize for Drama]] and three posthumous [[Tony Awards]].{{cite web|author=Haigh, Kenneth|url=http://www.pioneertheatre.org/press-room/season-archives/2010-2011-season/rent/directors-notes/ |title=Pioneer Theatre Company: Dramaturg's Notes |publisher=Pioneertheatre.org |date= |accessdate=February 4, 2013}} *[[Leah McSweeney]] (born 1982), founder and CEO of the female "Married to the MOB" (MTTM) clothing line.{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:QjojP7_OcEAJ:www.24teeth.com/press/download/married-to-the-mob-collaboration+&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESjB3ea6D9bGOlnX9zAwA2u6k7Nk_lkobQpEmxnWWfgs3e75miM9yHoIA3KqW4Whziit8L3I7bDTY_3vYHZNSIpWY8OWEDIEvBJ3er7qGxovBh92sZQdgcrjh36q2CVJf3WDTrcD&sig=AHIEtbRDGSZETU6PA0yHaS3TAQHDIL9FoA |title=Lacoste Launches Married to the Mob Lace Hi-Tops (press release) |publisher= MTTM and Lacoste|date= |accessdate=February 4, 2013}} *[[Andrew Wyatt]], musician and producer, lives on Spring Street.[http://www.songbird.me/#artists/andrew-wyatt-508ea880b3bfc000020008ea "Andrew Wyatt"] on Songbird.me ==In popular culture== There were two songs written about Spring Street: *"Spring Street" (2000), song by pop folk singer-songwriter [[Dar Williams]]{{cite web |url=http://www.bostonphoenix.com/archive/music/00/09/14/DAR_WILLIAMS.html |title=Folk tales; Dar Williams gets to heart of The Green World |author=Robins, Wayne |publisher=The Boston Phoenix |date=September 14–21, 2000 |accessdate=February 4, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304195203/http://www.bostonphoenix.com/archive/music/00/09/14/DAR_WILLIAMS.html |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} *"Spring Street" (2007), song by singer-songwriter [[Vanessa Carlton]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/21197838/site/todayshow/ns/today-entertainment/t/new-cds-leann-rimes-beirut/#.URQomGd_opA |title=New CDs from LeAnn Rimes, Beirut ; Vanessa Carlton, "Heroes & Thieves" |publisher=NBC News |date=October 8, 2007 |accessdate=February 7, 2013}} ==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist|33em}} '''Bibliography''' *{{cite gotham}} *{{cite aia5}} ==External links== {{commons category|Spring Street (Manhattan)}} *[https://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/20/arts/spring-street-a-stroll-for-all-seasons.html "Spring Street, a Stroll for All Seasons,"] by Richard Lourie, ''[[The New York Times]]'', June 20, 2003 {{Streets of Manhattan|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Lower Manhattan]] [[Category:SoHo, Manhattan]] [[Category:Streets in Manhattan]]

{{Infobox person | name = Tarek Aggad | image = Mr. Tarek Aggad.jpg | image_size = | caption = Tarek Aggad | birth_name = Tarek Omar Abdul Fattah Aggad | birth_date = {{birth based on age as of date |45|2017|01|16|df=yes}}<ref>{{cite web|author=Tarek Omar Abdul Fattah Al-Aggad |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=69400382&privcapId=30746670 |title=Tarek Omar Abdul Fattah Al-Aggad: Executive Profile & Biography |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date= |accessdate=2017-01-17}}</ref> | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = | education = | alma mater = [[Harvard University]] | occupation = Chairman, CEO and 27% owner, [[Arab Palestinian Investment Company]] | known for = | boards = | salary = | networth = | spouse = Shirine Aggad | parents = [[Omar Aggad]] | children = | relations = | website = }}
'''Tarek Omar Abdul Fattah Aggad ''' (born 1971/72) ({{lang-ar|تارک عمر عبدل عقاد}})is a [[Saudi]] businessman. He is the executive director of the Aggad Investment Company (AICO) - a Saudi diversified holding firm.<ref name="AICO">{{cite web|url=http://www.aico.com.sa/en/profile.html |title=Aico.com |website=Aico.com.sa |date= |accessdate=2016-04-11}}</ref> Aggad sits on the board of directors of several manufacturing, distribution and services companies in Palestine, Jordan and Saudi Arabia. In 1994, the [[Arab Palestinian Investment Company]] (APIC) was founded by his father [[Omar Aggad]]. It is an investment company with nine subsidiaries in the fields of consumer goods, pharmaceuticals, cars, retail and construction materials and Tarek Aggad is the chairman, CEO,<ref name="APIC_Home">{{cite web|title=APIC Home Page|url=http://www.apic.ps/english.php|website=APIC|accessdate=4 May 2016}}</ref> and owner of 27% of the company.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fox |first=Marisa |url=http://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/1.713347 |title=Panama Papers: Leaks reveal Abbas' son's $1m holding in company with ties to Palestinian Authority - Middle East News |publisher=[[Haaretz]] |date=2016-04-07 |accessdate=2017-01-17}}</ref>
Since its founding, APIC has become one of the largest operators in Palestine, employing over 1600 employees. Subsidiaries of APIC offer a wide array of products and services through distribution rights agreements with multinational companies that include Philip Morris, Procter & Gamble, Kellogg's, Hyundai, Chrysler, Dodge, Jeep, Alfa Romeo, Fiat, Fiat Professional, XL Energy, Abbott, B. Braun, Eli Lilly, GlaxoSmithKline, Sanofi Aventis and Nivea, among many others.<ref name="APIC_Home" />
==Early life== Aggad was born in Lebanon in 1971, the son of [[Omar Aggad]], and grew up in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia where he attended local schools. He holds a bachelor's degree in Economics from [[Harvard University]], US.<ref name="Tarek_Bio">{{cite web|title=Tarek O. Aggad, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer (APIC), Executive Director, Aggad Investment Company, Saudi Arabia|url=http://www.apic.ps/page.php?id=9c06y39942Y9c06|website=APIC|accessdate=4 May 2016}}</ref>
==Career== Aggad serves as a director on a number of boards including Aggad Investment Company, Palestine Investment Fund, Palestine Power Generation Company, Palestine Electric Company, Bank of Palestine, King Hussein Cancer Foundation, King’s Academy as well as other companies in Palestine, Jordan, and Saudi Arabia.<ref name="AICO" />
In 2001, Aggad was named a Global Leader of Tomorrow (GLT) at the World Economic Forum in Davos. In 2006, President Mahmoud Abbas appointed Aggad as a director of the Palestine Investment Fund, the investment arm of the Palestinian people (PIF).<ref name="Tarek_Bio" />
==Personal life== He is married to Shirine Aggad, and they have four children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kingsacademy.edu.jo/news-events/school-news/news-archive/2014-01/apic-establishes-scholarship-fund-palestinian-students-kings |title=APIC establishes scholarship fund for Palestinian students at King’s | King's Academy |website=Kingsacademy.edu.jo |date=2014-01-20 |accessdate=2016-04-11}}</ref>

{{Infobox book | name = The Strangest Secret | title_orig = The Strangest Secret | translator = | image = The Strangest Secret.jpg | alt = | image_size = | caption = | author = [[Earl Nightingale]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Personal-success literature|Personal-success]]
[[Self-help]] | genre = Non-fiction | publisher = | pub_date = 1957 | english_pub_date = | media_type = ([[Audiobook|Audio]], [[Paperback]], [[E-Book]]) | pages = 44 pages | isbn = 978-1603865579 | oclc = 1603865578 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Strangest Secret''''' was a 1957 spoken word record by [[Earl Nightingale]] which sold over one million copies and received the first Gold Record for the spoken word,{{cite web|url=https://www.last.fm/music/Earl+Nightingale|title=Earl Nightingale — Free listening, videos, concerts, stats and photos at Last.fm|website=Last.fm}} which helped launch the fields of business motivation and audio publishing. It was later adapted into print and video forms.{{cite web|url=http://www.awaken.com/2013/01/earl-nightingale/|title=Earl Nightingale - Awaken|website=www.awaken.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Earl-Nightingale-The-Strangest-Secret/release/10831837|title=Earl Nightingale - The Strangest Secret|website=Discogs}} ==Origin== In 1950 [[Earl Nightingale]] was inspired by the words "we become what we think about" in [[Napoleon Hill]]'s book [[Think and Grow Rich]] around the same time he bought an insurance agency. He provided weekly motivational speeches to the agency's sales staff. In 1956, he recorded a motivational speech to be played while he was on vacation. Nightingale's employees spread word of the speech, and demand for the recording grew so large that he and friend Lloyd Conant formed the Nightingale-Conant Corporation to manage sales.{{cite web|url=https://www.success.com/article/earl-nightingales-greatest-discovery|title=Earl Nightingale's Greatest Discovery|date=30 March 2009|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nightingale.com/authors/earl-nightingale.html|title=Earl Nightingale|website=www.nightingale.com}}{{cite web|url=https://edisciplinas.usp.br/pluginfile.php/3402848/mod_resource/content/1/16Earl_Nightingale_The+Strangest+Secret-Nightingale.pdf|title=Moodle USP: e-Disciplinas|first=Codely|last=Tecnologia|website=edisciplinas.usp.br}}{{cite web|url=http://www.earlnightingale.com/EarlNightingale___Audio.html|title=About Earl Nightingale|publisher=}} ==Content== The audio recording was later adapted into print form as a short 44 page essay. The teachings focus on nonconformity and self-education, and summarizes that "You are now, and you do become, what you think about."{{cite web|url=http://ideas.time.com/2013/10/24/the-10-best-self-help-books-youve-probably-never-heard-of/|title=The 10 Best Self-Help Books You've (Probably) Never Heard Of|first=Mitch|last=Horowitz|publisher=|via=ideas.time.com}}https://www.bizjournals.com/bizjournals/how-to/growth-strategies/2014/12/earl-nightingale-and-the-strangest-secret.html{{cite web|url=https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/616911-earl-nightingale-s-the-strangest-secret|title=The Strangest Secret Quotes by Earl Nightingale|website=www.goodreads.com}} ==In other media== Nightingale's recording has been redistributed in various mediums since its initial release. In 2018 [[Janice Bryant Howroyd]] released an updated version with her edits and enhancements, read from a female perspective.{{cite web|url=https://www.audible.com/pd/Self-Development/The-Strangest-Secret-Audiobook/B079SF95DN|title=The Strangest Secret|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://askjbh.com/2018/02/15/revealing-strangest-secret/|title=Revealing The Strangest Secret - Janice Bryant Howroyd|date=15 February 2018|publisher=}} ==References== {{more citations needed|date=November 2017}} {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Strangest Secret, The}} [[Category:Business books]] [[Category:Self-help books]] [[Category:1957 books]]
